comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Very docile and obliging cows. Try milking an untethered cow - usually, they just walk on leaving you and pail behind.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Excellent photo but I suspect it was a bit staged?  As Stu says milking in a field is likely to leave you sitting on your rear as the cow walks off looking for greener grass.  It does show a few changes from present day farms though, such as the horns on the cows, you'd never see them today.

comment.author: 10706647@N02
comment._content: I think I see a spancel on the back left leg of the cow, hidden by the bucket on the other side, fettering would have made the staging of the photo a bit easier.

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/10706647@N02] Well spotted. Never noticed it before!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] Me either! So thanks to [http://www.flickr.com/photos/wiblick] for spotting this...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here is the badly-transcribed Mannix family in the 1911 census. (The bio of Bishop Mannix above gives the farm location as Deerpark, Charleville, and the OS 25" shows Deerpark in Rathgoggan North, where a browse of the census shows only one Mannix family, and sure enough, the father is Timothy). If the girl milking above is 19, she is Helena, if 17, Lizzie, if 16, Mary. I don't think she is as young as Agnes at 13.
